src:
Office gibt es jetzt in einer App 05 Nov 2019, 12:49 by dj Microsoft Office lässt sich unterwegs jetzt in einer einzigen App nutzen. Microsoft hat eine neue Smartphone-App für iOS und Android lanciert, die alle Komponenten seiner Office-Suite vereint. Bisher waren Word, Excel und Powerpoint nur als eigenständige Apps verfügbar. Die neue App ist erstmal nur als Beta-Version für iOS und Android verfügbar. Bei ersterem wurden die 10’000 verfügbaren Plätze für Teilnehmer des Beta-Programms allerdings nach wenigen Stunden bereits ausgeschöpft. Android-Nutzer können die App aber weiterhin austesten. Zusätzliche Features Neben dem Zugriff auf die einzelnen Office-Komponenten hat die App auch noch einige neue Features. So kann man mit der Kamera des Smartphones ein Stück Papier aufnehmen und dies automatisch in Word-Dokument verwandeln. Gleiches gilt für eine Tabelle auf Papier, die in eine Excel-Datei umgewandelt werden kann. Auch PDFs lassen sich direkt aus mit der Kamera aufgenommenen Fotos erstellen. Diese kann man dann auch digital unterschreiben. Die neue Office-App gibt es derzeit nur für Smartphones, soll aber auch für Tablets erscheinen. Die bestehenden, eigenständigen Apps werden weiterhin unterstützt. OpenOffice vs. LibreOffice

LibreOffice und OpenOffice sind beides kostenlose Office-Suiten. 
Bild: DocumentFoundation/Apache

OpenOffice vs. LibreOffice

Sie sind die wohl wichtigste Alternative zu Microsoft Office, bei dem die Nutzung aller Programme inzwischen nur noch per teurem Einzelkauf oder monatlichem Abo möglich ist.
Bild: dj

OpenOffice vs. LibreOffice

Der Startbildschirm von LibreOffice konzentriert auf die zuletzt geöffneten Dokumente, neue Dateien lassen sich in der linken Spalte erstellen.
Bild: dj

" } , { "src": "https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/a093997c-611a-417c-bed4-613c8ef7e78f.jpeg?rect=0%2C55%2C2318%2C1302&w=1024&auto=format", "srcset": "https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/a093997c-611a-417c-bed4-613c8ef7e78f.jpeg?rect=0%2C55%2C2318%2C1302&w=1024&auto=format 1024w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/a093997c-611a-417c-bed4-613c8ef7e78f.jpeg?rect=0%2C55%2C2318%2C1302&w=750&auto=format 750w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/a093997c-611a-417c-bed4-613c8ef7e78f.jpeg?rect=0%2C55%2C2318%2C1302&w=620&auto=format 620w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/a093997c-611a-417c-bed4-613c8ef7e78f.jpeg?rect=0%2C55%2C2318%2C1302&w=450&auto=format 450w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/a093997c-611a-417c-bed4-613c8ef7e78f.jpeg?rect=0%2C55%2C2318%2C1302&w=320&auto=format 320w", "sizes": "90vw", "subHtml": "

OpenOffice vs. LibreOffice

Bei OpenOffice dreht sich beim Starten alles um neue Dokumente. Beide Office-Suiten bieten Programme für sechs Zwecke an: Textdokumente, Tabellen, Präsentationen, Datenbanken, Zeichnungen und mathematische Formeln.
Bild: dj

Das Zeichenprogramm heisst bei beiden Draw, hier die Variante von LibreOffice.

Das Präsentationsprogramm heisst Impress, hier bei OpenOffice zu sehen.

OpenOffice vs. LibreOffice

OpenOffice setzt auf eine klassische Benutzeroberfläche, wie sie alte Microsoft Office-Nutzer gewöhnt sind, mit den nötigen Icons in Leisten über dem Dokument.
Bild: dj

" } , { "src": "https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/327c3c62-921e-4b6c-b45b-66631a3ac603.jpeg?rect=0%2C0%2C2124%2C1193&w=1024&auto=format", "srcset": "https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/327c3c62-921e-4b6c-b45b-66631a3ac603.jpeg?rect=0%2C0%2C2124%2C1193&w=1024&auto=format 1024w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/327c3c62-921e-4b6c-b45b-66631a3ac603.jpeg?rect=0%2C0%2C2124%2C1193&w=750&auto=format 750w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/327c3c62-921e-4b6c-b45b-66631a3ac603.jpeg?rect=0%2C0%2C2124%2C1193&w=620&auto=format 620w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/327c3c62-921e-4b6c-b45b-66631a3ac603.jpeg?rect=0%2C0%2C2124%2C1193&w=450&auto=format 450w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/327c3c62-921e-4b6c-b45b-66631a3ac603.jpeg?rect=0%2C0%2C2124%2C1193&w=320&auto=format 320w", "sizes": "90vw", "subHtml": "

OpenOffice vs. LibreOffice

LibreOffice bietet diese Benutzerfläche auch an, hat aber optional auch noch andere Ansichten zur Auswahl. Hier etwa mit verschiedenen Tabs, ähnlich der Ribbon-Ansicht auf neueren Microsoft Office-Version.
Bild: dj

" } , { "src": "https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/77b0e056-1f3b-4ece-a631-3939a44aebad.jpeg?rect=0%2C58%2C2242%2C1260&w=1024&auto=format", "srcset": "https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/77b0e056-1f3b-4ece-a631-3939a44aebad.jpeg?rect=0%2C58%2C2242%2C1260&w=1024&auto=format 1024w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/77b0e056-1f3b-4ece-a631-3939a44aebad.jpeg?rect=0%2C58%2C2242%2C1260&w=750&auto=format 750w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/77b0e056-1f3b-4ece-a631-3939a44aebad.jpeg?rect=0%2C58%2C2242%2C1260&w=620&auto=format 620w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/77b0e056-1f3b-4ece-a631-3939a44aebad.jpeg?rect=0%2C58%2C2242%2C1260&w=450&auto=format 450w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/77b0e056-1f3b-4ece-a631-3939a44aebad.jpeg?rect=0%2C58%2C2242%2C1260&w=320&auto=format 320w", "sizes": "90vw", "subHtml": "

OpenOffice vs. LibreOffice

Standardmässig speichern die Office-Suiten Dokumenten in ihrem eigenen, offenen Dateiformat. LibreOffice ist auch mit den neusten Microsoft Office-Dateinformaten kompatibel und kann diese lesen und speichern.
Bild: dj

" } , { "src": "https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/80830b17-3b8c-4e7c-b2d6-19e87cf096f7.jpeg?rect=0%2C77%2C2256%2C1267&w=1024&auto=format", "srcset": "https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/80830b17-3b8c-4e7c-b2d6-19e87cf096f7.jpeg?rect=0%2C77%2C2256%2C1267&w=1024&auto=format 1024w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/80830b17-3b8c-4e7c-b2d6-19e87cf096f7.jpeg?rect=0%2C77%2C2256%2C1267&w=750&auto=format 750w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/80830b17-3b8c-4e7c-b2d6-19e87cf096f7.jpeg?rect=0%2C77%2C2256%2C1267&w=620&auto=format 620w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/80830b17-3b8c-4e7c-b2d6-19e87cf096f7.jpeg?rect=0%2C77%2C2256%2C1267&w=450&auto=format 450w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/80830b17-3b8c-4e7c-b2d6-19e87cf096f7.jpeg?rect=0%2C77%2C2256%2C1267&w=320&auto=format 320w", "sizes": "90vw", "subHtml": "

OpenOffice vs. LibreOffice

OpenOffice kommt nur mit älteren Microsoft Office-Dokumenten klar. Das hat einen einfachen Grund: Die Entwicklung von OpenOffice steht seit knapp vier Jahren quasi still.
Bild: dj

" } , { "src": "https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/c5b57daa-3df7-4b53-b339-05c234d5530a.jpeg?rect=0%2C5%2C1024%2C575&w=1024&auto=format", "srcset": "https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/c5b57daa-3df7-4b53-b339-05c234d5530a.jpeg?rect=0%2C5%2C1024%2C575&w=1024&auto=format 1024w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/c5b57daa-3df7-4b53-b339-05c234d5530a.jpeg?rect=0%2C5%2C1024%2C575&w=750&auto=format 750w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/c5b57daa-3df7-4b53-b339-05c234d5530a.jpeg?rect=0%2C5%2C1024%2C575&w=620&auto=format 620w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/c5b57daa-3df7-4b53-b339-05c234d5530a.jpeg?rect=0%2C5%2C1024%2C575&w=450&auto=format 450w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/c5b57daa-3df7-4b53-b339-05c234d5530a.jpeg?rect=0%2C5%2C1024%2C575&w=320&auto=format 320w", "sizes": "90vw", "subHtml": "

OpenOffice vs. LibreOffice

Um die Ursache dafür zu erklären, muss man noch mehr zurückblicken. OpenOffice entstand 2001 aus dem kommerziellen Produkt StarOffice und wurde als freie Software von einer Gemeinschaft von Freiwilligen entwickelt. Federführend war jedoch StarOffice-Macher Sun Microsystems. 
Bild: Keystone

" } , { "src": "https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/256b5265-c96d-41a8-adec-94978cfb54a8.jpeg?rect=0%2C0%2C1024%2C575&w=1024&auto=format", "srcset": "https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/256b5265-c96d-41a8-adec-94978cfb54a8.jpeg?rect=0%2C0%2C1024%2C575&w=1024&auto=format 1024w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/256b5265-c96d-41a8-adec-94978cfb54a8.jpeg?rect=0%2C0%2C1024%2C575&w=750&auto=format 750w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/256b5265-c96d-41a8-adec-94978cfb54a8.jpeg?rect=0%2C0%2C1024%2C575&w=620&auto=format 620w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/256b5265-c96d-41a8-adec-94978cfb54a8.jpeg?rect=0%2C0%2C1024%2C575&w=450&auto=format 450w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/256b5265-c96d-41a8-adec-94978cfb54a8.jpeg?rect=0%2C0%2C1024%2C575&w=320&auto=format 320w", "sizes": "90vw", "subHtml": "

OpenOffice vs. LibreOffice

Sun wurde in 2010 von Oracle übernommen. Danach brach das Verhältnis mit den meisten freiwilligen Entwicklern aufgrund von Meinungsverschiedenen über die Zukunft den Projekt zusammen. Sie spalteten sich ab und starteten LibreOffice.
Bild: Keystone

" } , { "src": "https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/c6f80e11-c12c-4910-8e77-558fd1eff279.jpeg?rect=0%2C11%2C994%2C558&w=1024&auto=format", "srcset": "https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/c6f80e11-c12c-4910-8e77-558fd1eff279.jpeg?rect=0%2C11%2C994%2C558&w=1024&auto=format 1024w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/c6f80e11-c12c-4910-8e77-558fd1eff279.jpeg?rect=0%2C11%2C994%2C558&w=750&auto=format 750w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/c6f80e11-c12c-4910-8e77-558fd1eff279.jpeg?rect=0%2C11%2C994%2C558&w=620&auto=format 620w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/c6f80e11-c12c-4910-8e77-558fd1eff279.jpeg?rect=0%2C11%2C994%2C558&w=450&auto=format 450w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/c6f80e11-c12c-4910-8e77-558fd1eff279.jpeg?rect=0%2C11%2C994%2C558&w=320&auto=format 320w", "sizes": "90vw", "subHtml": "

OpenOffice vs. LibreOffice

LibreOffice wird regelmässig mit neuen Features ausgestattet und Bugs werden relativ schnell behoben.
Bild: dj

" } , { "src": "https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/7bf4e588-1f9b-4a31-94a4-5fe38f8361a6.jpeg?w=1024&auto=format", "srcset": "https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/7bf4e588-1f9b-4a31-94a4-5fe38f8361a6.jpeg?w=1024&auto=format 1024w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/7bf4e588-1f9b-4a31-94a4-5fe38f8361a6.jpeg?w=750&auto=format 750w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/7bf4e588-1f9b-4a31-94a4-5fe38f8361a6.jpeg?w=620&auto=format 620w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/7bf4e588-1f9b-4a31-94a4-5fe38f8361a6.jpeg?w=450&auto=format 450w,https://production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/7bf4e588-1f9b-4a31-94a4-5fe38f8361a6.jpeg?w=320&auto=format 320w", "sizes": "90vw", "subHtml": "

OpenOffice vs. LibreOffice

OpenOffice wurde von Oracle an die Apache Foundation übergeben und fungierte ab dann unter dem Namen Apache OpenOffice. Seit 2015 gibt es bei OpenOffice keine neue Features mehr, das letzte Sicherheitsupdate stammt aus dem November 2018. Im Februar 2019 wurde eine Sicherheitslücke in OpenOffice entdeckt — diese wurde bis heute nicht geschlossen.
Bild: dj

OpenOffice vs. LibreOffice

Fazit: Es gibt keinen guten Grund, warum man heute noch OpenOffice statt Libreoffice nutzen sollte. OpenOffice ist quasi so, wie es LibreOffice vor vielen Jahren mal war. Letzteres ist in quasi allen Punkten überlegen. Und die Tatsache, dass für OpenOffice nicht mal mehr kritische Sicherheitsupdate zur Verfügung gestellt werden, sollte das Programm ganz alleine disqualifizieren.
Bild: Document Foundation

text:
Office is now available in an app 05 Nov 2019, 12:49 by dj Microsoft Office can now be used in one app on the go. Microsoft has launched a new smartphone app for iOS and Android that combines all the components of its office suite. So far, Word, Excel and PowerPoint were only available as stand-alone apps. The new app is initially only available as a beta version for iOS and Android. In the former, however, the 10'000 available seats for beta program participants were exhausted after a few hours. Android users can still test the app. Additional features In addition to accessing the individual Office components, the app also has some new features. So you can take a piece of paper with the camera of the smartphone and automatically turn this into Word document. The same applies to a spreadsheet on paper that can be converted to an Excel file. PDFs can also be created directly from photos taken with the camera. These can then be signed digitally. The new Office app is currently available only for smartphones, but should also appear for tablets. The existing, stand-alone apps will continue to be supported. OpenOffice relies on a classic user interface, familiar to old Microsoft Office users, with the necessary icons in bars above the document.

OpenOffice Vs. LibreOffice

LibreOffice also offers this user interface, but optionally also has other views to choose from. Here are some different tabs, similar to the ribbon view on the newer Microsoft Office version.

OpenOffice Vs. LibreOffice

By default, Office suites store documents in their own open file format. LibreOffice is also compatible with the latest Microsoft Office file formats and can read and save them.
Image: dj "}, {" src ":" https: // production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch. imgix.net/2019/5/16/80830b17-3b8c-4e7c-b2d6-19e87cf096f7.jpeg?rect=0%2C77252%2C1267&w=1024&auto=format "," srcset ":" https: // production-livingdocs- bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/80830b17-3b8c-4e7c-b2d6-19e87cf096f7.jpeg?rect=0%2C77%2C2256%2C1267&w=1024&auto=format 1024w, https: // production-livingdocs-bluewin -ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/80830b17-3b8c-4e7c-b2d6-19e87cf096f7.jpeg?rect=0%2C77%2C2256%2C1267&w=750&auto=format 750w, https: // production-livingdocs-bluewin- ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/80830b17-3b8c-4e7c-b2d6-19e87cf096f7.jpeg?rect=0%2C77%2C2256%2C1267&w=620&auto=format 620w, https: // production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch .imgix.net / 2019/5/16 / 80830b17-3b8c-4e7c-b2d6-19e87cf096f7.jpeg? rect = 0% 2C77% 2C2256% 2C1267 & w = 450 & auto = 450w format, https: // production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch. imgix.net/2019/5/16/80830b17-3b8c-4e7c-b 2d6-19e87cf096f7.jpeg? Rect = 0% 2C77% 2C2256% 2C1267 & w = 320 & auto = format 320w "," sizes ":" 90vw "," subHtml ":"

OpenOffice Vs. LibreOffice

OpenOffice only works with older Microsoft Office documents. There is a simple reason for this: The development of OpenOffice has been virtually silent for almost four years.
Image: dj "}, {" src ":" https: // production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch. imgix.net/2019/5/16/c5b57daa-3df7-4b53-b339-05c234d5530a.jpeg?rect=0%2C5%2C1024%2C575&w=1024&auto=format "," srcset ":" https: // production-livingdocs- bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/c5b57daa-3df7-4b53-b339-05c234d5530a.jpeg?rect=0%2C5%2C1024%2C575&w=1024&auto=format 1024w, https: // production-livingdocs-bluewin -ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/c5b57daa-3df7-4b53-b339-05c234d5530a.jpeg?rect=0%2C5%2C1024%2C575&w=750&auto=format 750w, https: // production-livingdocs-bluewin- ch.imgix.net/2019/5/16/c5b57daa-3df7-4b53-b339-05c234d5530a.jpeg?rect=0%2C5%2C1024%2C575&w=620&auto=format 620w, https: // production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch .imgix.net / 2019/5/16 / c5b57daa-3df7-4b53-b339-05c234d5530a.jpeg? rect = 0% 2C5% 2C1024% 2C575 & w = 450 & auto = 450w format, https: // production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch. imgix.net/2019/5/16/c5b57daa-3df7-4b53-b339-05c234d5530a.jpeg? rect = 0% 2C5% 2C1024% 2C575 & w = 320 & auto = format 320w "," sizes ":" 90vw "," subHtml ":"

OpenOffice Vs. LibreOffice

To explain the cause, you have to look back even more. OpenOffice was created in 2001 from the commercial product StarOffice and was developed as a free software by a community of volunteers. However, StarOffice maker Sun Microsystems was in charge. & Nbsp;

Rect = 0% 2C0% 2C1024% 2C575 & w = 450 & auto = format 450w, https: //production-livingdocs-bluewin-ch.imgix.net/2019/5 /16/256b5265-c96d-41a8-adec-94978cfb54a8.jpeg?rect=0%2C0%2C1024%2C575&w=320&a uto = format 320w "," sizes ":" 90vw "," subHtml ":"

OpenOffice Vs. LibreOffice

Sun was acquired by Oracle in 2010. After that, the relationship with most volunteer developers collapsed because of dissent over the future. They split off and started LibreOffice.

OpenOffice Vs. LibreOffice

LibreOffice is regularly updated with new features and bugs fixed relatively quickly.

OpenOffice Vs. LibreOffice

OpenOffice was handed over to the Apache Foundation by Oracle and then became known as Apache OpenOffice. & Nbsp; Since 2015, OpenOffice has had no new features, the last security update being November 2018 A security vulnerability was discovered in OpenOffice on February 2019 - it has not been closed until today.

OpenOffice Vs. LibreOffice

Conclusion: There is no good reason to use OpenOffice instead of LibreOffice today. OpenOffice is like LibreOffice many years ago. The latter is superior in virtually all points. And the fact that OpenOffice does not even provide critical security updates should completely disqualify the program.
